Award.AwardTitle: Cancer stem cell phenotyping: Establishing correlations and regulatory crosstalk between molecular markers and mechanical/rheological properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
While significant progress has been made in the fight against cancer largely due to drastic improvements in diagnostic techniques and treatment methods, therapies have been much less effective in combating those tumors that have spread to other organs, or metastasized. Specific subsets of cancer cells, known as cancer stem cells, may be primarily responsible for establishing these metastatic colonies, but the exact mechanisms are unknown, in no small part due to a lack of a universal molecular definition for cancer stem cells, through which these cells can be isolated and studied.
For this research project, the research team hypothesizes that cancer stem cells possess inherent rheological and viscoelastic properties that facilitate metastatic invasion and growth, and that these mechanical properties may be used to specifically identify cancer stem cells in complement to the molecular phenotype. The team will test this hypothesis by conducting studies that aim (1) to determine correlations between cellular mechanical properties and the CD44+/CD24- breast cancer stem cell phenotype, and (2) to identify regulatory crosstalk between cellular mechanical properties and the CD44+/CD24- breast cancer stem cell phenotype.
Intellectual Merit: This research seeks to address complex issues at the interface of the physical sciences and oncology. Therefore, principles and techniques from chemical engineering, biophysics, and medical sciences will be employed to achieve the study goals. The transformative studies and novel methodologies in this project will ultimately reveal molecular pathways regulating mechanical properties of cancer stem cells, subject matter that remains unaddressed by the scientific community to date.
Broader impacts: This project integrates multidisciplinary research with education and will have broader impacts on engineering and the life sciences, training of the next generation of bioengineering researchers, biotechnology development, and public health. The PI and co-PIs will mentor students participating in this research project through experiences that allow them to advance their own scientific knowledge as well as contribute to the wider scientific body, gain employment in engineering or biological fields, or pursue advanced degrees in these disciplines. This project will also have a significant impact on society and public health, as the research findings can be used to develop diagnostics, prognostics, and therapeutics to more specifically target deadly breast cancer stem cells.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metastasis is the culmination of an elaborate cascade of events in which cancerous cells separate from the primary mass, intravasate through blood vessel walls into the vasculature, traverse throughout the body, and finally seed new colonies in distant organs. Scientific literature has indicated roles for cancer stem cells and, separately, mechanical properties of the cancer cells in the promotion of metastasis. A significant knowledge gap exists, however, regarding a possible relationship between cancer stem cell biochemical composition and cancer stem cell mechanical properties in facilitating cancer progression. Several putative markers for cancer stem cells have been reported in scientific literature, although it is clear that these molecules do not effectively identify stem cells completely. Through this investigation, we have found differences between cancer stem cell (CSC)-like cells versus non-CSC-like cells using micropipette aspiration, microparticle tracking, and microfluidic channel devices, indicating that cell mechanical properties have potential for diagnostic use. In addition, we have successfully characterized cell adhesion properties related to mechanical properties. Finally, we have made advances in understanding epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and the reverse process MET and their effects on the breast cancer cell line mecahnical and adhesive properties used in this project. In total, this set of studies has provided a deeper understanding of mechanical and biochemical properties of cell subpopulations, as well as expanded general knowledge of cancer cell biology.  The impact of this project beyond science and technology is the societal benefit that will result from the deeper understanding of cancer stem cell properties: an improved basis for the development of diagnostics, prognostics, and therapeutic targets for the eradication of cancer.

Furthermore, multiple undergraduate and graduate students in physics, engineering, and biological sciences have been trained and mentored through this project.  These students have enrolled in doctoral programs and gained employment in public and private sectors.  Thus the impact of this project will continue as these former trainees make advances in biotechnology and fundamental understanding of engineering and sciences towards the improvement of human health and healthcare.


Last Modified: 10/27/2020
Modified by: Monica M Burdick
